Benefits : The major project benefit refers to the number of jobs that are expected to be created, which for the total project would correspond to an estimated 75,000-96,000 work-months of direct employment. In addition, it is assumed that jobs to be created indirectly, under various activities serving the construction industry, would correspond to about 40-50 percent of those to be created directly. Apart from job creation, the sub-projects will provide additional benefits from improved infrastructure services, protection of the environment and better health and education facilities. Risks : The project has several risks referring to: (i) maintaining a high labor content in the sub-projects; this risk would be mitigated by selecting labor-intensive sub-projects; (ii) maintaining an acceptable quality of works; this risk will be addressed by providing technical assistance and training to local consultants and contractors as well as NGOs; and (iii) ensuring sustainability of completed works; this risk would be addressed in the selection of sub-projects and in the development of NGOs' capabilities to assist communities in operation and maintenance. To respond to all these risks, flexibility has been built into the project to allow for adjustments, as necessary, in sub- project selection and in implementation arrangements.  REPUBLIC OF YEMEN PUBLIC WORKS PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT 1. INTRODUCTION A. Country Background 1.1 The Republic of Yemen (ROY) was established in May 1990, when the Yemen Arab Republic (YAR) in the north and the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen (PDRY) in the south were united. North Yemen had been ruled under a traditional system of governance and virtually closed to the outside world until 1962, when an army coup overthrew the last Iman and declared the formation of the YAR. South Yemen had been under British rule for a century and a half, with the port of Aden serving as an entrepot for British trading interests, until nationalist forces took over in 1967. PDRY became an independent country in 1970. 1.2 The unified Government had designated 1990-92 as a transition period, during which it concentrated on the difficult task of merging the two administrations and realigning the two economic systems. The transition period culminated in nation-wide parliamentary elections in April 1993. However, serioui difficulties arose leading to civil war from May to July 1994. Following the cessation of hostilities a coalition government was formed that is supportive of the current reform program. 1.3 To achieve sustainable growth and alleviate poverty, the Government has iecognized that a new development strategy is required. Given the inadequacies of the public sector and poor public finances, the source of growth for the future would be the private sector. Accordingly, the strategy for the modernization and development of the economy would be based upon a reduced role of the public sector, the development of the private sector, and export diversification. B. Economic Reform Program 1.4 In an effort to deal with the country's substantial econeonic problems, the Government is implemen,ing a comprehensive program of economic stabilization and structural adjustment with support from IDA and the IMF. In designing the economic reform program, the Government considered a number of factors. Central among them are: managing the fiscal dinmensions and consequences of the reform measures, stimulating a private sector supply response (that is, increased output and employment), and increasing economic efficiency. Within this framework, the Government's program focuses on three main areas: (a) stabilization to restore macroeconomic balance and reduce inflation; (b) structural reform and adjustment to stiimiulate medium- and long-term economic growth; and (c) social protection measures to minimize the negative impact on the vulnerable an(d the poor during adjustment. The imnplementation of the early phases of structural reforms would be supported by the Economic Reform Credit (ERC) (Credit No. 2840-YEM, approved on April 9, 1996). Mitigation of potential adverse effects of adjustment over the medium-term is to be achieved through different initiatives, including the Public Works Project and a proposed Social Fund Project. These initiatives would aim at social protection, delivery of social services to communities, and job creation.
 2 Public Works Project C. Rationale For IDA Involvement 1.5 The Project is fully consistent with the Bank Group's Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Yemen, presented to the Board on February 20, 1996. Economic reforms and poverty alleviation are among the key thrusts of the CAS. During its implementation, the Project would also, to the extent feasible, integrate the findings and recommendations of the Poverty Assessment study that is being prepared by using the data to be generated on the poverty profile, characteristics of the poor, and geographical distribution of poverty. The Project also complements ongoing and proposed IDA projects by providing infrastructure services and improving environmental and sanitary conditions. The Project, moreover, builds on the Emergency Recovery Project (Credit No. 2840-YEM) in Yemen as well as the experience in social funds and small public works programs in other countries. Further, the framework provided by the Project can play a catalytic role in attracting donor financing. II. THE PROJECT A. Project Objectives 2.1 The overall objective of the project is to mitigate potential adverse effects of economic adjustment. Specific objective is to generate an estimated 75,000-96,000 work-months of employment at a cost range of US$260 to US$350 per work-month. It is also expected that the project would help deliver much needed infrastructure services, improve environmental and sanitary conditions and enhance community participation in preparing and implementing sub-projects for civil works. Achievement of the project's development objective will be monitored through performance indicators and the findings will be reflected in quarterly progress reports and in quarterly audits. B. Project Description 2.2 The project would comprise: (a) small scale civil works in areas with above average unemployment rates for rehabilitation and/or extension in the following sectors: (i) waste management: waste water collection systems and storm water drains; cleaning of such systems; and solid waste collection and sanitary landfills; (ii) urban development: water distribution systems; repairing and paving (cobblestones) streets and footpaths; storm water drainage; flood protection; (iii) rurai development: road repairs; water supply systems; cleaning and repairing of irrigation canals; (iv) soil conservation: terracing and drainage works; small dams; and (v) health and education: health centers and school buildings. (b) development of a project management capability comprising a Steering Committee (SC) and a Project Management Unit (PMU) to be funded as the executive arm of the SC; and (c) provision of technical assistance services for: (i) the establishment of the PMU: including preparation of organizational and staffing structures; framework agreements for project management, personnel, administration, and operation; accounting and management information systems; (ii) investment programming, monitoring and review; (iii) sub-project preparation and implementation: including preparation of engineering design and tender documents, and construction supervision; (iv) support to local consulting and construction companies, including preparation for and organization of workshops; and (v) auditing.

III. PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION A. Procurement 3.1 Procurement of goods and works would be in accordance with the World Bank Guidelines for Procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits of January 1995 and revised January 1996. Procurement of goods, which would be limited to vehicles and office equipment for the PMU and locally made school furniture, could be procured according to national shopping for contract values of less than US$25,000 and international shopping for contract values of less than US$50,000, with an aggregate amount of US$450,000 and US$250,000 respectively. National and international shopping should be based on at least three quotations and, where relevant, from two countries. 3.2 The size of the civil works contracts would range from very small up to about US$250,000 to be awarded according to national competitive bidding (NCB) following local procurement procedures. A Country Procurement Assessment Report (CPAR) was recently completed, and with amendments as shown under the Project Implementation Summary in the Project File, the NCB procedures were found to be satisfactory. Conclusions reached are summarized as follows:
 Public Works Project S * present system for classification of civil works contractors and restriction of bidding to contractors in relevant categories of classification are acceptable to IDA; * contract amounts, where relevant, would be stated in US$ and, for payments to be made in local currency, these would, for evaluation purposes, be converted at prevailing market rates 28 days prior to bid opening; and payments would be made according to the market rates; and * standard bidding documents, issued in 1994 by the Ministry of Construction, Housing and Urban Planning (MCHUP) would be applied as appropriate. 3.3 For sub-projects in rural and to a lesser extent in urban areas, which are feasible for implementation by local communities or government agencies (e.g., municipalities), procedures under community participation (para. 3.19) would be accepted. For contracts exceeding US$250,000, if any, international competitive bidding (ICB) should take place. Following local advertisement the PMU would prepare a roster of potential local contractors including reference material, specializations and performance records, which should be maintained and updated as needed. 3.4 Consultant services would be used for: (i) specific short-term assignments for the establishment of the PMU and for annual progress and performance reviews; this would include foreign and local consultants; and (ii) the preparation of sub-project reports, engineering design and tender documents, and construction supervision; this would be carried out by local consultants (possibly through joint ventures with foreign consultants), and NGOs. The consultant contracts would be in the range of US$20,000 to US$300,000. The procedures for the invitation of consultant proposals with preparation of contract agreements should be according to Guidelines for the Use of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers and by the World Bank as Executing Agency of August 1981. The PMU would prepare a roster of potential consulting firms and NGOs, including reference material and information on specializations and performance records, which should be maintained and updated as needed. 3.5 The PMU would be staffed by local recruitment. Staff selection would be done competitively. The Project Director (PD) has already been appointed by the Steering Committee, on the basis of a short-list of candidates. IDA was consulted on the appointment and gave its no objection. For other key PMU positions, IDA has reviewed relevant job descriptions and qualification criteria, and interviewed suitable candidates whose appointments will be subject to IDA approval. It would be acceptable for civil servants to applv for the jobs, provided they leave their present employments to ensure their total integration in the PMU management structure. 3.6 All consultant contracts and goods and works contracts, estimated to cost more than US$50,000, as well as the first two contracts for goods and works regardless of value, would be subject to prior review by IDA. This is expected to result in a prior review of about 70 percent of all IDA-financed contracts. Given the preponderance of small contracts, this ratio is satisfactory. Of the remaining contracts, one in four would be subject to random post review. To ensure proper application of the procurement procedures under the Project, a procurement seminar was held in Sana'a in December 1995 and another one is scheduled for late-1996.

 10 Public Works Project D. Participatory Approach 3.21 The concept of the project emphasizes flexibility to ensure quick response; labor-intensive, small- scale civil works that do not require long preparation and implementation periods; and participation of communities and NGOs. The latter was influenced by the experience from other countries which indicates that such goals could best be achieved through active community participation to be mobilized with the support of NGOs. In Yemen, particularly in the rural areas. communities have traditionally participated in civil works projects by contributing in cash or in kind. The Project builds on this tradition, but also includes measures to involve support from a number of small NGOs, which have not to any larger degree, been active in community-based civil works programs. E. Project Monitoring 3.22 To ensure that the project meets its objectives, a set of performance indicators have been developed (Annex 6). These indicators focus on the number of jobs created and relevant costs per work- month. The PMU would establish a data base on unit costs for different works to be executed to enable a comparison among sub-projects and a refinement of its cost estimates. The SC and IDA would monitor project progress against these indicators on a quarterly basis, using the information obtained from the quarterly reports to be prepared by the PMU. 3.23 The SC/PMU and IDA would appoint a consultant to carry out an annual performance review. The findings and recommendations of the annual reviews would be discussed in workshops following the review process, with the participation of the stakeholders. The annual reviews would focus on the scope for improvements with specific proposals to be made regarding the functioning of the PMU and for the preparation and implementation of investment programs. During negotiations, assurances were given by the Government: (i) that quarterly progress reports including performance indicators would be submitted to IDA for review within 30 days after the end of the reporting period; and (ii) that annual performance reviews would take place each year during January with recommendations to be approved by the SC within one month. The annual review for 1999 should also be considered as the mid-term review. F. Project Supervision 3.24 Although the individual sub-projects are expected to be relatively simple, their country-wide distribution and large numbers would make the overall implementation complex. Moreover, the preparation of sub-projects with investment programs would be a continuous process during project implementation. This would require intensive supervision, and consequently, IDA resources have been shifted from the normal levels for preparation and appraisal towards implementation. The responsibility for project supervision would be delegated to the Resident Mission (RM). Staff from headquarters would be involved particularly in the annual reviews with an estimated annual input of about 10 staffweeks. The total input is estimated at 200 staffweeks. G. Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 3.25 The PMU, which is responsible for project budgeting and accounting, would keep separate accounts for the operation of the PMU, for the use of consultant services, for civil works and other contracts, and for the Special Account and Statement of Expenditures (SOEs). The PMU would install appropriate accounting/budgetary and management information systems, and for each year of project implementation, prepare a budget for its operational costs and investment program.
 Public Works Project 11 3.26 The Borrower is not in compliance with IDA audit reporting covenants. This issue would be discussed separately in the next Country Portfolio Performance Review with the Government. The PMU would be subject to quarterly and annual audits by independent auditors in accordance with internationally accepted standards. The audits would complement the annual performance review that would determine the applicability of the procedures (as detailed in the MOP) and assess the overall performance of the PMU. During negotiations, the Government gave assurances that auditors, acceptable to IDA, would be appointed for a 4-year period; annual audit reports would be submitted within 6 months from the end of the reporting period; quarterly interim audit reports would be submitted within 30 days following each quarter; and the audit reports would include separate statements for the Special Account and SOEs. H. Environmental Assessment 3.27 The proposed project has been classified as a category "B" project for the purpose of Operational Directive 4.01. A review of the characteristics of potential sub-projects concludes that the overall environmental impact would be positive. However, the environmental impact would vary among the sectors and works to be executed. Special attention would be paid to sub-projects covering waste water, solid waste disposal and storm water discharge. 3.28 Each sub-project report would assess the potential environmental impact of the works to be undertaken and specify mitigative actions to be taken. During sub-project selection, any sub-project for which the mitigative measures specified are not adequate to alleviate the adverse environmental impact would be rejected. The PMU would prepare for each investment program a Summary Environmental Assessment and include under its annual reviews relevant environmental aspects. The content of a Summary Environmental Assessment is shown under the Project Implementation Summary in the Project File. To ensure that environmental aspects of sub-projects are adequately addressed, the PMU would appoint an environmental specialist to report directly to the PD. I. Project Sustainability 3.29 Sub-projects, when completed, would be handed over to the sector ministries, NGOs and communities for operation and maintenance. Long-term sustainability would thus be subject to the capacity of these entities to maintain and operate the completed works. In the selection of sub-projects an assessment would be made of expected future operational arrangements, and to what extent concurrent actions would be taken on improvements in operational performance. Operational arrangements would also be reviewed by IDA sector staff in the context of the development strategy being followed in the sector. IV. PROJECT BENEFITS AND RISKS A. Benefits 4.1 The major project benefit refers to the number of jobs that are expected to be created. An analysis of typical sub-projects for the first investment program (Annex 7) shows that each US$1 million investment would generate jobs in the range of 2900 to 3800 work-months, assuming a distribution of investments in urban/rural areas in the ratio 70/30 and a labor content in the range of 30-40 percent of contract values. For the total project, this would correspond to an estimated 75,000 to 96,000 work-months of employment at a cost of US$335 to US$260 per work-month. In addition, it is assumed that jobs to be created indirectly, under various activities serving the construction industry, would correspond to about 40- 50 percent of those to be created directly. A sensitivity analysis would show that a change in the distribution
 12 Public Works Project of investments in urban/rural areas from 70/30 to 50/50 would increase the number of work-months by about 10-15 percent. 4.2 Apart fromjob creation, sub-projects will provide additional benefits from improved infrastructure services, protection of the environment and better health and education facilities. These benefits would be significant, but it is not cost-effective to evaluate them for every sub-project. The project will include high priority, low investment sub-projects for rehabilitation of physical assets to increase their value and return to full utilization. Because of the small size and diverse location of sub- projects, it is not cost-effective to carry out formal economic analysis to estimate internal rates of return. B. Risks 4.3 Potential risks and actions taken or to be taken for their mitigation are: (a) maintaining a high labor content in sub-projects to be selected: * selection criteria have been agreed to that labor-intensive sub-projects are chosen; the number of jobs to be created will be monitored as a performance indicator; and IDA in its approval of investment programs will pay particular attention to the labor content; (b) developing a project implementation capacity through the establishment and operation of the SC and the PMU, which would be funded as the executive arm of the SC: PMU staff will be appointed on contract basis at a salary level comparative to the private sector; IDA will review and approve all appointments; and provisions will be made for annual performance evaluations and for the replacement of non-performing staff; (c) avoiding selection and financing of low priority sub-projects, or sub-projects that have been initiated under various arrangements but not completed: * PMU is designed to be autonomous and have high quality staff, with review of its activities by the SC, auditors and IDA staff; (d) maintaining an acceptable quality of works taking into account present competence and availability of local consulting firms, NGOs and small scale contractors: * local consulting firms and NGOs can use non-Yemeni staff financed under their contract agreements with PMU as needed; workshops and training sessions will be organized; and specifications and quality requirements will be standardized and closely supervised; and (e) assuring sustainability of completed works: * this is taken into account in the selection criteria; NGOs would be developed to assist communities in operation and maintenance; and concurrent actions are taken in different sectors on improvements in operational performance in the course of other donor and IDA operations;

 Annex 4 Page 1 of 2 REPUBLIC OF YEMEN PUBLIC WORKS PROJECT Sub-Project Selection Criteria 1. The Public Works Project will cover a number of sub-projects in different sectors and dispersed on a country-wide basis, which will be summarized under investment programs. The investment programs will be prepared taking into account: selection of sub-projects according to specific criteria; the need for multi-sectoral coverage; and specific conditions for achieving a balanced geographical distribution. These matters are addressed in the paragraphs below providing a further elaboration of the overall project objectives, which are to: - create employment, particularly among the poverty groups; - deliver much needed infrastructure services; - improve environmental and sanitary conditions; and - promote community participation. 2. The sub-project selection criteria address: (a) the labor content as a percentage of contract values, which should be in the range of 30- 40 percent and only less than 25 percent in exceptional cases. This implies: - the selection of works that, by nature, are labor intensive and contain a low level of imported material; and the preference of small contracts, where the use of special equipment is less economical; (b) improvements in infrastructure services regarding: number of beneficiaries and related investment costs per capita; unit costs for different works to be executed with ceilings to be established; and assessment and comparison of benefits to be achieved; (c) improvements in environmental conditions regarding: an assessment of the need for mitigative actions; and rejection of sub-projects with an adverse environmental impact;
 Annex 4 Page 2 of 2 (d) degree of community (or stakeholder) involvement: involvement in sub-project identification and preparation; contribution (cash or labor) in works execution; and responsibility for operation and maintenance; (e) poverty alleviation regarding: extent to which sub-projects will be located in areas with above average poverty levels and/or unemployment rates; (f) sustainability regarding: - extent to which proposed works form a part of a larger development program; - current and expected future arrangements for operation and maintenance; and - degree of cost recovery and need for recurrent budgetary allocations. 3. For each sub-project a report, according to a standard format, will be prepared, which will include an evaluation of the above criteria. These have also been summarized in a table format as shown under Appendix 1. It is proposed that any sub-project with a rating of less than 50 (to be expressed as a percentage of maximum score) should be excluded. The selection criteria will be reviewed annually, taking into account the development and refinement of a data and information base, with adjustments to be made as appropriate. 4. In the composition of investment programs the Steering Committee should provide guidelines, to be reviewed annually, on geographical distribution, coverage of different sectors, and balance between urban and rural areas. In rural areas, community participation will be more predominant than in urban areas, while in urban areas, because of higher population density, the investments per capita would be less and a larger number of people can be reached. In some sectors, which would have a preference, a larger labor input will be achieved because of the nature of works. The above considerations might effect the sectoral and urban-versus-rural distribution of sub-projects, which will be reviewed for each individual investment program. 5. The thrust of the project should be job creation, with emphasis on unskilled workers, and thus poverty alleviation, and therefore geographical areas with an above average poverty level and unemployment rate should be targeted. On these matters information is rare, but some indications would be provided through a poverty assessment, which is under preparation, and through needs assessments, that will be prepared where justified. The information base will improve during the course of project implementation, which will enable an increasing refinement in sub-project selection.

doc.repnme: Republic of Yemen - Public Works Project
doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Public Works Project is to mitigate potential adverse effects of economic adjustment. Specific objective is to generate an estimated 75,000-96,000 work-months of employment at a cost range of US$260 to US$350 per work-month. The project will also help deliver much needed infrastructure services, improve environmental and sanitary conditions and enhance community participation in preparing and implementing sub-projects for civil works. The project will comprise the following components: 1) small scale civil works in areas with above average unemployment rates for rehabilitation and/or extension in the following sectors: waste management, urban development, rural development soil conservation, and health and education; 2) development of a project management capability comprising a steering committee (SC) and a project management unit (PMU) to be funded as the executive arm of the SC; and 3) provision of technical assistance services for: (a) the establishment of the PMU; (b) investment programming, monitoring and review; (c) sub-project preparation and implementation; (d) support to local consulting and construction companies; and (e) auditing.
